results.title: A Cold war
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, BBC and Lionheart TV International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
Dr. Christopher Andrews unravels the complex origins of the Cold War. From the earliest days of the Bolshevik Revolution, he traces the growth of mutual distrust and fear between the Capitalist West and the world’s first Communist state - an uneasy coexistence during the inter-war years which finally ended in a complete divorce, dividing the post-war world into two camps and so threatening it with destruction.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Dent, BBC and Lionheart TV International

results.title: Lenin's secret files
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
‘Lenin’s secret files’ is part of an acclaimed investigative history series from the BBC which pursues new evidence and research of familiar historical events and figures. In this program the ethnic background, family, political ruthlessness and illness of Vladimir Illich Lenin, who, in 1917 led the Russian Revolution, are followed. It uses the personal archives of Lenin - which have only been accessible since the collapse of communism, to present a definitive portrait of one of history’s key figures.

results.title: On nature's trail
results.creator_credit: Jason Rosenfield and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Four young nature enthusiasts meet each Saturday morning in their local park where they let their imagination roam free, while learning many principles of ecology as they relate to everyday life. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students.

results.title: Totally Gross Anatomy
results.creator_credit: Donald M. Cooper and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Our bodies are machines in motion, capable of sheer strength, complicated thought and graceful coordination all at the same time. This is due to a network of specialised systems and teams of organs that work in perfect harmony. This series investigates those major systems, using actual footage of working organs as well as clear demonstrations with everyday materials to illustrate both the way in which they function and the purpose they serve. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students.

results.title: The Bones and muscles
results.creator_credit: Gail Prensky, JWM Productions and National Geographic Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Totally Gross Anatomy”.
Using 3D animation and x-ray footage, this video reveals the network of 206 bones and more than 600 muscles that combine to make up the human musculo-skeletal system. Students will investigate the composition of bones (the spongy inner layer, the compact outer layer and the types of marrow inside bones), and the importance of joints, tendons and muscles in ensuring that the skeleton not only gives the body a flexible framework, but also protects important internal organs. The video concludes with a series of assessment questions and answers designed to ensure that students understand basic concepts related to bones and muscles. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gail Prensky, JWM Productions and National Geographic Television

results.title: History of Australian art
results.brief_description: This is a definitive collection of important Australian artists from the period 1788-1991. It investigates the European traditions, the Heidelberg School and the beginnings of Post-Impressionism and abstraction. From Margaret Preston to Brett Whitely, controversial modernist art, and the influence of American styles such as Abstract Expressionism. It also investigates experimental art - Performance and Happenings, the influence of Feminism and the international and commercial success of Aboriginal art. Key works from galleries across Australia and a lively commentary provide an informed history emphasising critical developments in Australian art. Includes high-resolution images, multi-level presentations and commentary, full lists of artists with additional information, close-up views of any part of each image and a detailed study guide with key to the works.

results.title: A History of Australian art. Part 3 (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian art”.
This is a definitive collection of important Australian artists from the period 1970-1991. It investigates experimental art - Performance and Happenings, the influence of Feminism and the international and commercial success of Aboriginal art. Key works from galleries across Australia and a lively commentary provide an informed history emphasising critical developments in Australian art. Includes high-resolution images, multi-level presentations and commentary, full lists of artists with additional information, close-up views of any part of each image and a detailed study guide with key to the works. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Macintosh LC, 2MB RAM, 1MB free disc space, 8 bit colour card, system 6.0.5 or higher, CD ROM XA. IBM PC and Compatible; Windows 3.1 or higher, 4MB RAM, 4MB free disk space, VGA display, MPC Compatible CD ROM XA.

results.title: Wonders of the universe
results.creator_credit: David Taylor and York Films of England
results.brief_description: Produced for England’s The Discovery Channel, this informative series uses actual pictures and footage from various astronomical observatories, including the Hubble space telescope and computer-generated simulation to explore the main features of our universe which have fascinated humankind for thousands of years. The narration is in easy to understand language and would be eminently suitable for Upper Primary to Tertiary level students.
